Can We Please Move Away From Usernames?

February 29, 2016
|In Life Hacks
|By Tony

If I have to enter one more username on a form I’m going to crack. Ok maybe that’s a bit extreme, but you get the point. Providing usernames on registration form is so 1999. It’s still a mystery to me why any sane developer even thinks to include it on their websites or apps. Before you turn the page, permit me to provide some information to turn this rant into a dissertation.

Theory

Every good application or database designer understands and values the concept of indices and keys. Not the keys you use to start your car, but pieces of data that allow for fast searching and retrieval of information. When it comes to website/app registration and login, the two most collected keys are username and email address. The question I postulate is: do we still need usernames? To answer my own question , no we do not.

A Brief History of Usernames

In the beginning of modern web and mobile applications (which I consider the last twenty years), most companies would require users of their properties to create a unique username. Why? For fun? A strange form of narcissism, allowing people to showcase their creativity or intelligence? The answer is information retrieval. The username was the key by which one logged in and subsequently was tracked. Sites built on CMSs such as Wordpress were notorious for this, even to this day. This required customers and users alike to be forced to remember not only another password, and all sites had different password requirements, but another useless random combination of letters and numbers only for that site. One would think crazy practices would have went the way of Pets.com, but unfortunately for today’s web user, the antiquated practice of collecting usernames is still happening.

Practical Application

As a developer of dozens of websites and applications, I’ve moved on from usernames years ago. My coder friends and my users agree with this approach. Both parties are taxed by the presence of this element; developers for all the extra work in collecting, validating, and storing it, users for having to remember another meaningless combination of letters and numbers. The benefits are marginal, the potential for error high. Besides that, they add an extra step in the login process for when users forget, only frustrating them further and decreasing the likelihood of conversion. While the cost of storing data has decreased in recent years with the advent of cloud computing, good user experience is paramount.

Beyond the storage concern, since usernames are identifiers which must be universally-unique throughout space and time of the web property/ies, once they are created they are stuck forever, even if the user leaves the website. For this reason, most websites do not allow users to change their proud usernames after registration, so ladiesman01134 will be stuck with you on that important job board site forever.

A Real Solution

The solution for this larger than necessary nuisance is simply to switch to email address unequivocally across the Internet as the login key for web & application forms. This can be rolled out relatively easily, so long as the company is already collecting email address and appropriated room for it. One company that does this correctly throughout their web properties is, you guessed it, Google. To be transparent, I am not singling out Google simply because I happen to work there. Take the global login form:

One field (on the first view) asking for your email address, the following with one field asking for the password. Obviously Google is very email-centric (being the owners of Gmail notwithstanding), but there is no mention of username throughout the Google registration or login process. By leveraging a simple, unique identifier such as email address, companies can simplify logins, roll out new authenticated features, and provide better user experiences to all of their customers.
